hedline.hl1: The best, the brightest and 'The Bell Curve.'

block.p: Malcolm W. Browne cites Richard J. Herrnstein and Charles Murray's argument that they can prove that intelligence tests are not systematically biased against blacks because "if the S.A.T. is biased against blacks, it will underpredict their college performance." Since their examination of "hundreds of studies" reveals that such tests do correctly predict performance, they conclude that these tests are therefore not biased.

Malcolm W. Browne cites Richard J. Herrnstein and Charles Murray's argument that they can prove that intelligence tests are not systematically biased against blacks because "if the S.A.T. is biased against blacks, it will underpredict their college performance." Since their examination of "hundreds of studies" reveals that such tests do correctly predict performance, they conclude that these tests are therefore not biased.

This is an astonishingly blatant reasoning error. If tests are biased, they are so not because of personal biases of the testers, but because of widely shared cultural biases. The same biases, then, would be at work in the institutions in which the performance of blacks is being predicted. In that case, biased tests would of course correctly predict performance in equally biased institutions. HARRY BROD Newark, Del.
